TI Reaction rate constants with OH radicals at 253-328 K and atmospheric
   implications for (CF3)(2)CHOCxH(2x (+1)) (x=1, 2, 3)
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Global warming potential; Hydrofluoroethers; OH radicals; Atmospheric
   lifetime; Photochemical ozone creation potential
ID OZONE CREATION POTENTIALS; ORGANIC-COMPOUNDS; CHEMISTRY;
   HYDROFLUOROETHERS; KINETICS
AB Rate constants at 253-328 K for reactions of OH radicals with (CF3)(2)CHOCH3 (k6), (CF3)(2)CHOCH2CH3 (k7), and (CF3)(2)CHOCH2CH2CH3 (k8) were studied using a relative rate method. Data on k6, k7, and k8 (2.13 x 10(-13), 1.07 x 10(-12), and 1.92 x 10(-12) cm(3) molecule(-1) s(-1), respectively) were obtained at 298 K. The corresponding radiative efficiencies (0.103, 0.034, and 0.021 W m(-2) ppb(-1)) were calculated from infrared absorption spectra measured at room temperature. Global warming potential (GWP(100)) was estimated to be 5, < 1, and < 1, respectively, and the photochemical ozone creation potential in all cases was < 10.
C1 [Li, Wei; Zhang, Xiaoling] Beijing Inst Technol, Sch Chem & Chem Engn, 5 South Zhonguancun St, Beijing 100081, Peoples R China.
   [Li, Wei; Qin, Sheng; Zhang, Qiyan; Guo, Zhikai] Zhejiang Res Inst Chem Ind, State Key Lab Fluorine Greenhouse Gases Replaceme, Hangzhou 310023, Zhejiang, Peoples R China.

TI The ferromagnetism of Sn-1 (-) xFexO2 films and nanostructure arrays
   prepared by magnetron sputtering
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Sn1-xFexO2 films; Nanostructure arrays; Diluted magnetic semiconductors
   (DMS); Anisotropic ferromagnetism
ID ROOM-TEMPERATURE FERROMAGNETISM; ELECTRONIC-STRUCTURE; VACANCY; FE;
   SEMICONDUCTOR
AB The amorphous Sn1- xFexO2 films deposited at room temperature by magnetron sputtering were annealed in air and Ar respectively, and the saturation magnetization of Sn1- xFexO2 films annealed in Ar is much higher than the samples annealed in air. Crystallized Sn1- xFexO2 films were obtained at the deposition temperature above 570 degrees C, which exhibited remarkable room-temperature ferromagnetism and magnetic anisotropy. The Sn1- xFexO2 films have largest saturation magnetic moment of 0.255 mu(B)/Fe at x= 0.033. In addition, Sn1- xFexO2 nanostructure arrays were produced by glancing angle sputter deposition. The Sn1- xFexO2 nanostructure arrays possess larger atomic magnetic moment, which is 0.561 mu(B)/Fe (x= 0.059), compared with the flat films.
C1 [Chen, Shutian; Li, Zhengcao; Zhang, Zhengjun] Tsinghua Univ, Sch Mat Sci & Engn, Beijing 100084, Peoples R China.
   [Chen, Shutian] Nanjing Inst Technol, Sch Mat Sci & Engn, Nanjing 211167, Jiangsu, Peoples R China.
   [Chen, Shutian] Jiangsu Key Lab Adv Struct Mat & Applicat Technol, Nanjing 211167, Jiangsu, Peoples R China.

TI Theoretical study of the photodissociation reaction of methanol
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
ID BASIS-SETS; DYNAMICS; ATOMS; CH3OH; PATHWAYS; ENERGY; GAS
AB The photodissociation of methanol, which is an important radical source on interstellar ices, was studied using quantum chemistry calculations. Surface hopping simulations using the time-dependent density functional theory were performed, and the potential energy curves of the low-lying excited states were analyzed using the second-order multireference perturbation theory to reveal the reaction mechanism in the gas phase. We showed that the generation of CH3O would more frequently occur than that of CH2OH on the S-1 state in contrast to the ground state. We also discuss why the ratio of CH3O and CH2OH differs between the gas and solid phases.
C1 [Kayanuma, Megumi; Shoji, Mitsuo; Furuya, Kenji; Umemura, Masayuki; Shigeta, Yasuteru] Univ Tsukuba, Ctr Computat Sci, 1-1-1 Tennodai, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 3058577, Japan.
   [Aikawa, Yuri] Univ Tokyo, Dept Astron, Bunkyo Ku, 7-3-1 Hongo, Tokyo 1130033, Japan.

TI Adsorption of CO2 on biphasic and amorphous calcium phosphates: An
   experimental and theoretical analysis
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Calcium phosphate; CO2 adsorption; DFT calculations
ID HYDROXYAPATITE 0001; SURFACE; SEPARATION; BINDING; MODEL; FTIR; AREA
AB Calcium phosphates are suggested as a CO2 adsorbent via pressure swing adsorption. Amorphous calcium phosphate (ACP) and biphasic calcium phosphate (BCP) (composed of hydroxyapatite and beta-tricalcium phosphate) were investigated for the capture/immobilization of the gas. A fluidized bed was set up to assess the levels of CO2 adsorption by ACP and BCP. A gaseous mixture was synthesized, mimicking the conditions for possible industrial use. The results show a significant reduction in CO2 concentrations. Using DFT calculations, we show that CO2 adsorption increases the stability by reducing the surface energy. The energies involved and preferential adsorption sites were also theoretically predicted.
C1 [Souza, F. S.; Galvao, B. R. L.; Arapiraca, A. F. C.; da Silva, S. N.; Pinheiro, I. P.] CEFET MG, Ctr Fed Educ Tecnol Minas Gerais, Av Amazonas 5253, BR-30421169 Belo Horizonte, MG, Brazil.

TI Functionalized few-layered graphene oxide embedded in an organosiloxane
   matrix for applications in optical limiting
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Graphene oxide; Organosiloxane; Sol-gel; Optical limiting; Z-scan
ID EXFOLIATED GRAPHENE; REDUCED GRAPHENE; CARBON; SURFACE; NONLINEARITIES;
   NANOPARTICLES; FABRICATION; ABSORPTION; HYBRIDS
AB Few-layered graphene oxide is covalently functionalized with (3-Aminopropyl) triethoxysilane and incorporated into an organosiloxane matrix using a sol-gel technique. Nonlinear optical and optical limiting properties of functionalized few layered graphene oxide embedded in an organosiloxane matrix (f-GO/sol) are studied in the nanosecond regime at 527 nm. In a Z-scan study, f-GO/sol samples exhibit superior nonlinear optical and optical limiting responses in comparison to their graphene oxide precursor due to increased covalent crosslinking of graphene oxide and organosiloxane molecules. These significant improvements are attributed to the combined mechanisms of nonlinear absorption and nonlinear scattering, due to graphene-silica nanostructures and thermally-generated microplasmas.
C1 [Maharjan, Surendra; Liao, Kang-Shyang; Wang, Alexander J.; McElhenny, Brian P.; Curran, Seamus A.] Univ Houston, Dept Phys, Inst NanoEnergy, Houston, TX 77204 USA.

TI Hierarchical core-shell tungsten oxide/TiO2 nanowires as an effective
   photocatalyst
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Semiconductors; Nanocomposites; Pulsed laser deposition
ID TIO2/WO3; NANOPARTICLES; DEGRADATION; DEPOSITION; FILMS
AB In this letter, tungsten oxide(WO3)/TiO2 core-shell nanowires were prepared by depositing a layer of TiO2 nanoparticles on the surface of WO3 nanowires via a pulse laser deposition method. These TiO2 nanoparticles are qusi-aligned wire-like structure on the surface of WO3 nanowires. The number of laser pulses during the deposition adjusts the TiO2 thickness. When used as photocatalyst, these core-shell nanowires have photocatalytic activity in the degradation of rhodamine B (RhB). The photo-induced electron-hole separation effect between WO3 and TiO2 contributes to the improvement of the photocatalystic activity. This makes these nanowire arrays having good potential in wastewater treatment.
C1 [Ding, Ran; Wang, Kang; Hong, Kunquan; Zhang, Yun; Cui, Youxia] Southeast Univ, Sch Phys, Nanjing 211189, Jiangsu, Peoples R China.

TI Photoinduced reversible isomerization of 9H-fluorene into 1H-fluorene by
   means of hydrogen-atom migration and the lowest electronically excited
   triplet state studied by matrix-isolation FTIR spectroscopy
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Fluorene; Photoinduced hydrogen-atom migration; Matrix-isolation
   infrared spectrum; Electronically excited T-1 state
ID DENSITY-FUNCTIONAL-THEORY; ISOLATION INFRARED-SPECTROSCOPY; IR
   SPECTROSCOPY; RESONANCE RAMAN; FLUORENE; CARBAZOLE; SPECTRUM;
   DIBENZOFURAN; TRANSITIONS; NAPHTHALENE
AB Photoinduced reversible intramolecular hydrogen-atom migration between 9H-fluorene and 1H-fluorene isolated in an Ar matrix is found by FTIR spectroscopy with an aid of DFT calculation. The forward isomerization from 9H-fluorene to 1H-fluorene occurs upon UV irradiation (lambda >= 295 nm), while the backward isomerization occurs lambda >= 320 nm light irradiation. The less stable isomer, 1H-fluorene, is identified by comparison of the measured IR spectrum with the corresponding simulated spectral pattern obtained at the B3LYP/6-31 + + G(d, p) level. In addition, an IR spectrum of 9H-fluorene in the T-1 state is measured during UV irradiation (lambda >= 275 nm).
C1 [Kumakura, Takehiro; Akai, Nobuyuki; Nakata, Munetaka] Tokyo Univ Agr & Technol, Grad Sch BASE Bioapplicat & Syst Engn, Naka Cho, Koganei, Tokyo 1848588, Japan.

TI A novel low-temperature phase change material based on stearic acid and
   hexanamide eutectic mixture for thermal energy storage
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Stearic acid; Hexanamide; Eutectic mixture; Phase change materials;
   Thermal energy storage
ID FATTY-ACIDS; LATENT-HEAT; BINARY-MIXTURES; RELIABILITY; SYSTEMS; DIAGRAM
AB The stearic acid (SA) - hexanamide (HA) binary mixtures were prepared, and the phase diagram and Tammann plot were constructed. The differential scanning calorimetry results indicated that a eutectic composition formed by 46.2 mol% SA and 53.8 mol% HA melted at the temperature of 331.15 K with a latent heat of 176.62 J.g (-1). Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy and X-ray diffraction results revealed that SA and HA were just physical mixture. The results of thermogravimetric analysis and 100 thermal cycles test respectively manifested that eutectic mixture had good thermal stability and reliability. Therefore, eutectic mixture is promising for thermal energy storage application.
C1 [Ma, Guixiang; Sun, Jinhe; Zhang, Yue; Jing, Yan; Jia, Yongzhong] Chinese Acad Sci, Qinghai Inst Salt Lakes, Key Lab Comprehens & Highly Efficient Utilizat Sa, Xining 810008, Qinghai, Peoples R China.

TI Ab initio molecular dynamics simulation of methanol and acetonitrile:
   The effect of van der Waals interactions
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
ID REACTIVE FORCE-FIELD; LIQUID METHANOL; WATER; MIXTURES; APPROXIMATION;
   REAXFF
AB We employed PBE and BLYP semi-local functionals and the van der Waals density functional of Dion et al. (2004) (vdW-DF) to investigate structural properties of liquid acetonitrile and methanol. Among those functionals the vdW-DF is the only one that correctly predicts energy minima in inter-molecular interactions between acetonitrile molecules. We found that van der Waals interactions have a negligible effect on H-bonds in methanol chains. However, it significantly increases chain packing resulting in a more dense liquid in comparison to the other two functionals. The overall trend is that the vdW-DF tends to overestimate density and bulk modulus, meanwhile the semi-local functionals tend to underestimate density. Thus, van der Waals interactions play an important role in the properties of liquids in which much stronger dipole-dipole interactions are present.
C1 [Dias, Rafael F.; aa Costa, Cleidineia C.] Univ Fed Vicosa, Dept Fis, BR-36570000 Vicosa, MG, Brazil.
   [Dias, Rafael F.; aa Costa, Cleidineia C.; Manhabosco, Taise M.; de Oliveira, Alan B.; Matos, Matheus J. S.; Soares, Jaqueline S.; Batista, Ronaldo J. C.] Univ Fed Ouro Preto, Dept Fis, BR-35400000 Ouro Preto, MG, Brazil.
RP Batista, RJC (reprint author), Univ Fed Ouro Preto, Dept Fis, BR-35400000 Ouro Preto, MG, Brazil.
EM batista.rjc@ufop.edu.br
RI batista, ronaldo JC/N-8736-2015; Matos, Matheus J. S./F-8789-2012; de

TI Effect of double or single bonding in C-H stretching signal propagation
   in organic molecules. A computational study
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
ID ENERGY-TRANSPORT; TRANSITION-STATE; RELAXATION; FLOW; CONDUCTION;
   OLIGOMERS; DYNAMICS
AB The objective of this study is to evaluate vibrational energy propagation of a C-H stretching signal on unsaturated organic molecules and the effect of saturation in a specific site of those molecules using ab-initio molecular dynamic relaxation simulations. The results show that the inclusion of saturation at a specific site at the double bonded organic chain blockade the protrusion of C-H stretching vibrational energy at this site. As the saturation involves the change from double to single bonding regime, the effect is possibly originated by the loss of electron resonance at this specific site.
C1 [Mino-Galaza, German] Univ Bernardo O Higgins, Fac Ingn Ciencia & Tecnol, Santiago, Chile.
   [Pablo Staforelli, Juan] Univ Concepcion, Dept Phys, 160-C, Concepcion, Chile.
   [Gutierrez, Gonzalo] Univ Chile, Fac Ciencias, Dept Fis, Grp NanoMat, Casilla 653, Santiago, Chile.
RP Mino-Galaza, G (reprint author), Univ Bernardo O Higgins, Fac Ingn Ciencia & Tecnol, Santiago, Chile.

TI Two polyhedral frameworks of an M12L24 spherical complex revealed by
   replica-exchange molecular dynamics simulations
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Coordination complex; Spherical complex; Polyhedron; Self-assembly;
   Replica-exchange molecular dynamics
ID STRUCTURAL SWITCH
AB We performed replica-exchange molecular dynamics (REMD) simulations for self-assembly of an M12L24 spherical complex that consists of 12 palladium ions (M) and 24 bent ligands (L). We found two metal-ligand frameworks with polyhedral structure were mainly observed with almost equal probability. One of the two frameworks, which has the lowest potential energy, has the same symmetry, T-d, as the framework determined by the X-ray crystallographic analysis. The other framework, which has a slightly higher probability, has a different symmetry, C-3v. The latter framework is less likely to be observed experimentally than the former because of the difficulty in crystallization.
C1 [Tachi, Yuhei; Okamoto, Yuko] Nagoya Univ, Grad Sch Sci, Dept Phys, Nagoya, Aichi 4648602, Japan.
   [Sato, Sota] Univ Tokyo, Sch Sci, Dept Chem, Bunkyo Ku, 7-3-1 Hongo, Tokyo 1130033, Japan.

TI CFCs replacements: Reactivity and atmospheric lifetimes of a series of
   Hydrofluoroolefins towards OH radicals and Cl atoms
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE CFCs replacements; Hydrofluoroolefins; Arrhenius expressions; OH
   radicals; Cl atoms
ID OZONE CREATION POTENTIALS; GAS-PHASE REACTIONS; ORGANIC-COMPOUNDS;
   HALOCARBON MEASUREMENTS; RATE COEFFICIENTS; CHLORINE; HYDROXYL;
   CHEMISTRY; PRODUCTS; HYDROCARBON
AB A study of the temperature dependence of the gas-phase reactions of OH radicals and Cl atoms with a series of hydrofluroolefins: 2-fluoropropene (CH3CF=CH2), hexafluoroisobutylene ((CF3)(2)C=CH2) and (E/Z)-1,2,3,3,3pentafluoropropene ((E/Z)-CF3CF=CHF) has been performed. The relative-rate technique was used to determine rate coefficients over the temperature range 287-313 K.
   This work constitutes the first temperature dependence study of OH radicals and Cl atoms with 2-fluoropropene and (E/Z)-1,2,3,3,3-pentafluoropropene and for the reaction of Cl with hexafluoroisobutylene. Atmospheric implications are discussed with particular reference to the rate coefficients obtained as a function of the temperature.
C1 [Rivela, Cynthia B.; Teruel, Mariano A.; Blanco, Maria B.] Univ Nacl Cordoba, Fac Ciencias Quim, Dept Fis Quim, Inst Invest Fis Quim Cordoba INFIQC,CONICET, Ciudad Univ, RA-5000 Cordoba, Argentina.

   Ikeda-Fukazawa, Tomoko
TI Surface structures and properties of forsterite in crystalline and
   glassy states
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Forsterite; Surface structure; Molecular dynamics calculation
ID MG2SIO4
AB To investigate the surface structures of forsterite in crystalline and glassy states, we performed molecular dynamics calculations. The result shows that a low-density layer exists in the surface. The amplitude of the thermal vibrations of atoms in the surface layer is higher than that of the internal parts due to a low coordination number. The enhanced thermal vibrations of atoms in the surface layer cause a surface melting. The surface effects have important implications for forsterite states in meteorites and interstellar space.
C1 [Nishizawa, Junya; Ikeda-Fukazawa, Tomoko] Meiji Univ, Dept Appl Chem, Kawasaki, Kanagawa 2148571, Japan.
RP Ikeda-Fukazawa, T (reprint author), Meiji Univ, Dept Appl Chem, Kawasaki, Kanagawa 2148571, Japan.

TI Humidity controlled light transmittance of salt modified porous
   polymeric membranes
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Breath figure self-assembly; Relative humidity; Polyurethane; Porous
   polymeric film
AB Addition of LiCl into polymers creates continuous phase of porous structure that transports vapor in a rate much faster than existing products. Porous networks allow light to transmit in a humid condition and transmission proceeds through interconnected pores and refraction of filled water. The magnitude of transmittance is controlled by salt content, porosity and the level of humidity.

TI Core-shell structured TiO2@In2O3 for highly active visible-light
   photocatalysis
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Nanocomposites; Semiconductors; TiO2@In2O3; Core-shell structure
ID DOPED TIO2; PERFORMANCE; FABRICATION; FILMS; WATER
AB Core-shell structured TiO2@In2O3 with high visible-light photocatalytic activity have been successfully fabricated by solvothermal method. The as-obtained products were characterized by field transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD) and UV-visible diffuse reflectance spectra (UV-vis DRS). Structural characterizations demonstrated that the In2O3 layers were comprised of nanocrystallites ca. 14 nm in size and displayed rough surfaces. The UV-vis DRS data showed that In2O3 greatly expanded the visible light absorption band edge of TiO2. The results revealed that the obtained TiO2@In2O3 with core-shell structure showed enhancement of the visible-light photocatalytic activity to degrade methyl orange (MO) comparing with the pure TiO2 and In2O3 products.
C1 [Du, Quanchao] Shaanxi Univ Technol, Coll Chem & Environm Sci, Hanzhong 723001, Shaanxi, Peoples R China.

TI The valence and ion-pair states of the N2I2 van der Waals complex
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
ID DYNAMICS; AR; HE; AR-CENTER-DOT-CENTER-DOT-CENTER-DOT-I-2; TRANSITIONS;
   EXCITATION; ENERGIES; CLUSTERS; SPECTRA; NE
AB The N2I2(E0(g)(+)) van der Waals complexes have been observed and studied for the first time. Analysis of the luminescence excitation spectra as well as luminescence spectra themselves in the spectral ranges, where the I-2(D0(u)(+) -> X0(g)(+), beta 1(g) -> A1(u) and D'2(g) -> A'2(u)) transitions can occur, has been carried out. Branching ratios of the iodine molecule state formation and vibronic level population have been determined. Ab initio calculations of the N2I2(X0(g)(+)) complex ground state at complete basis set limit are performed. It is shown that it has two stable, parallel and linear, isomers separated by an energy barrier. The parallel isomer is observed in our experiments. Binding energies of the N2I2(X0(g)(+),v(X) = 0,n(X) = 0,B0(u)(+),v(B) = 19,n(B) = 0) as well as the some spectroscopic parameters of the N2I2(E,v(E) = 0, 3) complexes have been also estimated.

TI Concerted bond switching mechanism coupled with one-electron transfer
   for the oxygen-oxygen bond formation in the oxygen-evolving complex of
   photosystem II
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
ID EFFECTIVE CORE POTENTIALS; SCALE QM/MM CALCULATIONS; CHEMICAL-BONDS;
   MOLECULAR CALCULATIONS; STRUCTURAL-CHANGES; CAMN4O5 CLUSTER; HYBRID-DFT;
   S-3 STATE; WATER; PHOTOSYNTHESIS
AB We here precisely analyzed the electronic structures during the oxygen-oxygen (O-O) bond formation of the oxygen-evolving complex (OEC) in photosystem II (PSII) based on the quantum mechanics/molecular mechanics (QM/MM) calculations. Changes in the spin density and the chemical indices derived from the natural orbitals suggested that the O-(5)-O-(6) bond formation proceeds with a concerted bond breaking of the Mn-4-O-(5) coupled with the through-bond one-electron transfer from the O-(6) site to the Mn-4 site (Mn-4(IV) -> Mn-4(III)). This mechanism can be best described as a Concerted Bond Switching (CBS) mechanism, which is a nonradical reaction of the O-(5)-O-(6) bond formation.
C1 [Shoji, Mitsuo] Univ Tsukuba, Ctr Computat Sci, Tennodai 1-1-1, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 3058577, Japan.
   [Isobe, Hiroshi] Okayama Univ, Res Inst Interdisciplinary Sci, Kim Ku, Tsushima Naka 1-1-1, Okayana, Okayama 7008530, Japan.
   [Yamaguchi, Kizashi] Osaka Univ, Inst Nanosci Design, Toyonaka, Osaka 5608531, Japan.
   [Yamaguchi, Kizashi] Osaka Univ, Inst Sci & Ind Res, Suita, Osaka 5670047, Japan.
   [Yamaguchi, Kizashi] Handairigaku Technores, Toyonaka, Osaka 5600043, Japan.

TI Comment on 'Dye-sensitized solar cells using Aloe Vera and Cladode of
   Cactus extracts as natural sensitizers' [Chem. Phys. Lett. 679
   (2017)97-101]
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
AB The purpose of this Comment is to point out an inconsistency in the above mentioned Letter, concerning the calculation of the efficiency of the dye-sensitized solar cells under investigation, to avoid irritations of other researchers working with similar material under similar measurement conditions and of reviewers evaluating their manuscripts.

TI Response to Comment on "Dye-sensitized solar cells using Aloe Vera and
   Cladode of Cactus extracts as natural sensitizers"
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Dye-sensitized solar cells; TiO2 film; Nanomaterials; Green energy;
   Natural dyes
AB The purpose of this response is to point out several inconsistencies and incomplete information provided in the comment on our Letter, concerning the minor calculation error in the efficiency of the dye-sensitized solar cells. The comment was written to cover Dr. Ehrmann groups failed attempt in fabricating solar cells with ultra-low efficiency and unnecessarily targeted only selected groups like us and other authors listed in her references. We have decided to respond since the comment was not peer-reviewed by experts in the area and published as-it-is as we felt we should provide proper justification along with the supporting evidence.

TI Determination of mixture properties via a combined Expanded Wang-Landau
   simulations-Machine Learning approach
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Mixtures; Phase equilibria; Wang-Landau sampling; Neural networks
ID MONTE-CARLO-SIMULATION; PHASE COEXISTENCE; TRANSITION; BINARY; ENERGY;
   ARGON; THERMODYNAMICS; PREDICTION; KRYPTON; MODELS
AB Even-sampling methods have allowed for the evaluation of the density of states, providing access to all thermodynamic properties at once. However, these methods become highly intensive for multicomponent systems. We develop a combined Expanded Wang-Landau-Machine Learning (EWL-ML) approach to predict efficiently and accurately the thermodynamics of mixtures. We show that only a fraction of the EWL results is necessary to train a neural network and provide results in very good agreement with experiments. The resulting speed-up is expected to considerably increase the range and complexity of systems that can be studied with even-sampling methods.
C1 [Desgranges, Caroline; Delhommelle, Jerome] Univ North Dakota, Dept Chem, Grand Forks, ND 58202 USA.
RP Delhommelle, J (reprint author), Univ North Dakota, Dept Chem, Grand Forks, ND 58202 USA.

   Caroline/0000-0003-4171-5750

TI A new method of synthesis well-dispersion and dense Fe3O4@SiO2 magnetic
   nanoparticles for DNA extraction
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Magnetic nanoparticles; Core-shell; DNA extraction; Fe3O4@SiO2
ID GENOMIC DNA; SILICA
AB A new method was developed for preparing monodisperse Fe3O4@SiO2 magnetic core-shell nanoparticles via three steps. The obtained nanoparticles exhibit high saturation magnetization, good surface topography and dispersion as characterized by FTIR, SEM and VSM. The experimental results of hydrochloric acid treatment show that the obtained nanoparticles have excellent acid resistance and stable and compact silicon coating. The magnetic core-shell nanoparticles were further tested for purification of plasmid DNA from E. coli DH5a cells. The result of purification leaded to better adsorption, elution and purity results in comparison with isolated commercial extraction kit.

TI DNA/RNA hybrid mesoscopic model shows strong stability dependence with
   deoxypyrimidine content and stacking interactions similar to RNA/RNA
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE DNA/RNA hybrid; Peyrard-Bishop DNA model; DNA/RNA stability; Hydrogen
   bonds; Stacking interaction
ID DNA-RNA HYBRID; STRUCTURAL-PROPERTIES; POLYPURINE TRACT; HYDROGEN-BONDS;
   DUPLEXES; RECOGNITION; STRAND; CONFORMATION; FLEXIBILITY; SEQUENCES
AB Despite the importance of DNA/RNA hybrids, a mesoscopic approach is still missing. We developed a mesoscopic model for DNA/RNA hybrids and obtained the complete parametrization from published melting temperatures. The new parameters show very clearly the reduced strength of the hydrogen bond of dArU base pairs, resulting in a weakened stabilization of the double helix and a strong stability dependence on deoxypyrimidine content. The stacking parameters show no correlation to B-DNA, however we obtain a moderate correlation to A-RNA. We discuss some example sequences with variable deoxypyrimidine contents and for polipurine tracts (PPT).
C1 [Martins, Erik de Oliveira; Barbosa, Vivianne Basilio; Weber, Gerald] Univ Fed Minas Gerais, Dept Fis, BR-31270901 Belo Horizonte, MG, Brazil.

TI Modelling of reaction-diffusion process at carbon nanotube - Redox
   enzyme composite modified electrode biosensor
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Nonlinear reaction diffusion equation; New homotopy perturbation method;
   Biosensor; Redox enzyme electrode; Carbon nanotube
ID SELF-ASSEMBLED MONOLAYERS; HOMOTOPY PERTURBATION METHOD;
   HORSERADISH-PEROXIDASE; POLYMER-FILMS; KINETICS; TRANSPORT;
   ELECTROCHEMISTRY; CATALYSIS
AB A mathematical model of transport and kinetics of substrate, redox-mediator in surface deposited film is discussed. The model is based on the system of non-linear reaction diffusion equations containing a nonlinear term related to the Michaelis-Menten kinetic of the enzymatic reaction. The non-linear reaction diffusion equations in amperometric biosensors are solved using New Homotopy perturbation method. The effect of various parameters on current density is discussed. Numerical simulation for concentration profile and flux was carried out and compared with the analytical results. A satisfactory agreement is noted. A graphical procedure for estimating the kinetic parameters and sensitive analysis is suggested.
C1 [Lakshmanan, Rajendran] Acad Maritime Educ & Training, Kanathur 603112, Tamil Nadu, India.

TI Superprismane: A porous carbon allotrope
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE First-principle calculations; Carbon allotrope; Linear band dispersion;
   Semiconductor
ID PLANAR TETRACOORDINATE CARBON; TOTAL-ENERGY CALCULATIONS
AB In this study, a novel form of three-dimensional (3D) porous carbon allotropes (superprismane) was predicted and its thermal, mechanical as well as electronic properties were evaluated by means of first-principle density functional theory based calculations. Calculated cohesive energy (E-coh), bulk modulus (B), shear modulus (G), Young's modulus (E), Vickers hardness (H-upsilon) and phonon band dispersions at zero pressure reveal the excellent thermodynamical and mechanical stability of superprismane. Results show that, superprismane is superhard, ductile and semiconducting in nature. Further, superprismane comprises of low effective mass fermions and serves as potential candidate in blue to ultraviolet optoelectronic applications.
C1 [Subramanian, Venkatesan] CSIR, Cent Leather Res Inst, Inorgan & Phys Chem Dept, Madras 600020, Tamil Nadu, India.

TI Structure and luminescence properties of Zn3V2O8 yellow phosphor for
   white light emitting diodes
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Zn3V2O8; Crystal structure; Luminescence mechanism; Phosphors
ID COLOR-TUNABLE LUMINESCENCE; ENERGY-TRANSFER; VANADATE; EU3+; CRYSTAL; MG
AB Extensive attention has been focused on the development of rare-earth-free phosphors, due to their low cost, good absorption and emission properties. However, the yellow light emitted phosphors with good quantum yield and thermal stability are still urgent Herein, we successfully prepare the single-phase Zn(3)V(2)O(8 )yellow phosphor through a solid state reaction method. The as-prepared phosphors present a broad absorption band in UV/NUV region, and exhibit an intense broadband emission spectrum under the NUV light excitation at 365 nm. The Zn3V2O8 phosphors also show excellent luminescence performance including strong emission intensity, long PL lifetime, high quantum yield, and good thermal stability. Moreover, this sample obtains a CIE coordinate of (0.364, 0.486) in the yellow light region. Therefore, the Zn3V2O8 phosphors can be considered as a novel yellow light source for w-LED devices.
C1 [Qian, Tingting; Fan, Bin; Wang, Hongliang; Zhu, Shikun] Chinese Acad Sci, Res Ctr Ecoenvironrnental Sci, State Key Lab Environm Aquat Chem, Beijing 100085, Peoples R China.

TI NaCa2Si3O8(OH)/PEDOT:PSS composite nanowires as anode materials for
   lithium-ion batteries
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Silicates; Composites; Functional; Energy storage and conversion
ID REDUCED GRAPHENE OXIDE; SILICATE; PERFORMANCE; CARBON; NANOCOMPOSITES
AB NaCa2Si3O8(OH)nanowires with diameters of 100-150 nm and lengths up to several tens of micrometers have been successfully prepared on a large scale via a one-step hydrothermal method. The poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene): poly(styrenesulfonate) (PEDOT:PSS)-coated NaCa2Si3O8(OH) nanowires have also been prepared via a simple dip-and-dry technique. The electrochemical performances of the NaCa2Si3O8(OH) and NaCa2Si3O8(OH)/PEDOT:PSS nanowires were investigated. Compared with pure NaCa2Si3O8(OH) nanowires, the NaCa2Si3O8(OH)/PEDOT:PSS composite nanowires exhibit improved electrochemical properties of higher discharge/charge capacity and better cycling reversibility. This is the first time that NaCa2Si3O8(OH) nanostructures were used as anode materials in lithium-ion batteries, and the present work will greatly expand the application fields of NaCa2Si3O8(OH).
C1 [Zhang, Shaoyan; Ci, Lijie; Mu, Wei; Lu, Min] Shijiazhuang Univ, Coll Chem Engn, Shijiazhuang 050035, Hebei, Peoples R China.
RP Zhang, SY (reprint author), Shijiazhuang Univ, Coll Chem Engn, Shijiazhuang 050035, Hebei, Peoples R China.

TI Symmetry breaking and switchable thermal dielectric behaviors triggered
   by order-disorder phase transition in a neutral co-crystallized organic
   adduct
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
ID TEMPERATURE; FERROELECTRICITY; PEROVSKITES; MOLECULE
AB Reversible crystal state structural phase transitions molecular materials without metal have been received increasing interest recently. Here we successfully synthesized a novel ternary neutral co-crystallized organic adduct hexamethylenetetramine.1-adamantane carboxylic acid.chloroform, 1, which accompanies with an interesting reversible phase transition close to the zero temperature (263 K). We confirmed this reversible phase transition by its switchable thermal dielectric behaviors and unit cell constants anomalies around the phase transition temperature (T-c). X-ray single crystal diffraction analysis above (1-RTP) and below (1-LTP) T-c suggests that the order-disorder motion from the adamantane ring in 1-adamantane carboxylic acid triggered the reversible phase transition.
C1 [Chen, Shao-Peng; Wang, Chang-Feng; Zhou, Hai-Tao; Tan, Yu-Hui; Wen, He-Rui; Tang, Yun-Zhi] Jiangxi Univ Sci & Technol, Sch Met & Chem Engn, Ganzhou 341000, Peoples R China.

TI Singlet oxygen photogeneration by ethanolic extract of Syzygium cumini
   fruits: Theoretical elucidation through excited states computations
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE TDDFT; Singlet oxigen; Anthocyanin; Syzygium cumin
ID NATURAL DYES; SOLAR-CELL; TIO2; PHOTOSENSITIZERS; SENSITIZER; OXIDATION;
   LIGHT
AB The ethanolic extract of Syzygium cumini fruits was characterized and evaluated in the photogeneration of singlet oxygen (O-1(2)) under visible light radiation. This process was studied from a theoretical approach by the survey of the generated electronic excited states, after photoexcitation of the most abundant anthocyanin of the extract, i.e. delphinidin-3,5-diglucoside. It was determinated that the adiabatic energy of the optimized T-1(pi(H-1) -> pi(L)*) state was 1.55 eV and that the overall energy transfer releases similar to 0.58 eV in an exothermic process. Therefore, this state is the responsible of promoting electron transfer reactions and subsequent formation of O-1(2) through illumination.
C1 [Diaz-Uribe, Carlos; Lopez, Maria] Univ Atlantico, Grp Fotoquim & Fotobiol, Puerto Colombia 081007, Colombia.
   [Rodriguez-Serrano, Angela] Univ Duisburg Essen, Dept Computat Biochem, D-45117 Essen, Germany.
   [Schott, Eduardo] Pontificia Univ Catolica Chile, Fac Quim, Dept Quim Inorgan, Santiago, Chile.
   [Munoz, Amner] Univ Norte, Grp Invest Quim & Biol, Puerto Colombia, Colombia.
   [Zarate, Ximena] Univ Autonoma Chile, Fac Ingn, Inst Ciencias Quim Aplicadas, Providencia, Chile.

TI The effects of oxidation on the electronic, thermal and mechanical
   properties of antimonene: First-principles study
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Antimonene; Oxidation; Lattice dynamics; Thermal conductivity;
   First-principles
ID BOLTZMANN TRANSPORT-EQUATION; TOTAL-ENERGY CALCULATIONS; PHONON
   TRANSPORT; CONDUCTIVITY; MONOLAYERS; SOLVER; FILMS; SB
AB We calculate the electronic, thermal and mechanical properties of antimonene with different oxygen compositions (Sb, 25b-O and 25b-2O). Results show that the band gaps gradually decrease with the increase of the oxidation degree. We also study the lattice thermal conductivities of the three materials and find that the oxidation would greatly reduce the lattice thermal conductivity k of antimonene which is due to the decline of corresponding phonon lifetime. In addition, oxidation reduces the stiffness of antimonene. Our work provides a new perspective for the adjustment of thermal transport which will facilitate the design of thermal materials.
C1 [Zhang, Shuai-Kang; Cheng, Yan] Sichuan Univ, Coll Phys Sci & Technol, Inst Atom & Mol Phys, Chengdu 610065, Sichuan, Peoples R China.
   [Zhang, Tian] Sichuan Normal Univ, Sch Phys & Elect Engn, Chengdu 610066, Sichuan, Peoples R China.
   [Hu, Cui-E] Chongqing Normal Univ, Coll Phys & Elect Engn, Chongqing 400047, Peoples R China.
   [Chen, Qi-Feng] China Acad Engn Phys, Inst Fluid Phys, Natl Key Lab Shock Wave & Detonat Phys Res, Mianyang 621900, Peoples R China.

TI Acyl thiourea derivatives: A study of crystallographic, bonding,
   biological and spectral properties
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Acyl thioureas; Crystal structure; Spectroscopic analysis; RAHB model;
   Biological assays
ID HYDROGEN-BONDS; CRYSTAL-STRUCTURE
AB The study of two new acylthiourea derivatives (Ar-CO-NH-CS-NH-R) are focused on the bonding interactions supported by X-ray, NMR, UV-Vis, Raman and IR spectroscopy, and NBO, AIM and Hirshfeld surface analysis. The RAHB model is proposed to explain some structural properties. The molecules are stabilized by intra-molecular NH center dot center dot center dot O bonds arranged in the lattice as centre-symmetric dimers held by inter-molecular NH center dot center dot center dot S bonds. The dimers are linked to each other through NH center dot center dot center dot O bonds giving rise to a chain, ribbon-like structure in the network. In vitro bacterial growth inhibition, biofilm formation, biosensor and biofilm metabolic activity were tested considering the broad bioactivity of acylthioureas.

TI Unique phenomena induced by an exchange interaction between two
   graphene-like Ising nanoparticles in an applied transverse field
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Phase diagrams; Magnetizations; Reentrant phenomena; Nanoparticle; The
   EFT
ID MAGNETIC-PROPERTIES; NANOISLAND; TEMPERATURE; FRUSTRATION; NANOWIRE;
   COBALT
AB The phase diagrams and the magnetizations of graphene-like nanoparticles which are constructed from two paramagnetic honeycomb units and an inter-unit exchange interaction r are investigated by using the effective-field theory with correlations. They have exhibited some characteristic phenomena, such as the reentrant phenomena, when the value of r is larger than r = 1.0 and a transverse field is applied.

TI Using a collagen heterotrimer to screen for cation-pi interactions to
   stabilize triple helices
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Collagen; Salt bridge; Energetic contribution; Prediction of stability
ID PEPTIDES; CHAIN
AB As one of non-covalent forces to stabilize protein, cation-pi interactions in collagen have been received much attention. Three chains of collagen form its characteristic secondary structure, triple helices. Based on a collagen heterotrimer, abc, a library containing 15 mutant peptides was built to characterize the stabilizing effects of 24 pairwise cation-pi interactions. The six stabilizing pairs, axial FK, YK, WK, RF, and RW, and lateral RF, have been identified, among which only axial RF frequently occurs in natural collagen sequences. This suggests that cation-pi interactions might not be optimized in natural collagen.
C1 [Zheng, Hongning; Liu, Han; Hu, Jinyuan; Xu, Fei] Jiangnan Univ, Sch Biotechnol, Key Lab Carbohydrate Chem & Biotechnol, Minist Educ, 1800 Lihu Ave, Wuxi 214122, Peoples R China.
RP Xu, F (reprint author), Jiangnan Univ, Sch Biotechnol, Key Lab Carbohydrate Chem & Biotechnol, Minist Educ, 1800 Lihu Ave, Wuxi 214122, Peoples R China.

TI The comparative study of new carboxylated 1,3-indanedione sensitizers
   with standard cyanoacetic acid dyes using co-adsorbents in
   dye-sensitized solar cells
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Dye-sensitized solar cells; Co-adsorbents; Organic sensitizer; DFT
ID PHENOTHIAZINE-BASED DYES; ORGANIC-DYES; AB-INITIO; PI-A; ACCEPTOR;
   CONTINUUM; DESIGN; UNITS
AB Two new carboxylated 1,3-indanedione sensitizers (MPhe-ind and BPhe-ind) were synthesized and their dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSC) performance were compared with the corresponding standard cyanoacetic acid sensitizers (MPhe-cn and BPhe-cn). The carboxylated 1,3-indanedione sensitizers have shown almost 100 nm enhanced absorption curves compared to the cyanoacetic acid dyes with an extended IPCE curve up to 800 nm. Despite greater absorption and electrochemical properties, the synthesized dyes showed moderate efficiencies (2.10% and 2.67%) than standard dyes. The low electron injection efficiency and recombination of carboxylated 1,3-indanedione might be responsible for low efficiency. Detailed investigation studies have been performed and complemented with the theoretical studies.

TI Tuning the interparticle distances in self-assembled gold nanoparticle
   films with their plasmonic responses
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Au NPs; Interface; Self-assembly; Interparticle distance; Localized
   Surface Plasmon
ID SURFACE-ENHANCED RAMAN; ALKANETHIOLATE MONOLAYERS; SILVER NANOPARTICLES;
   SCATTERING; SPECTROSCOPY; MOLECULES; SHAPE; SERS; SIZE; SUPERLATTICES
AB This study presents the fabrication and characterization of imine-functionalized Au nanoparticle (Au NP) film using Poly (ethyleneimine) (PEI) as a reducing and surface stabilizing reagent The PEI-capped Au NPs can be self-assembled at the water-hexane interface by adding alcohol containing alkanethiol. Furthermore, large-area film made from PEI and alkanethiol-capped Au NPs is produced on a glass substrate with varying interparticle distances that can be controlled by the alkyl chain lengths, ranging from C2 (ethanethiol), C4 (1-butnaethiol), C6 (1-hexanethiol), C8 (1-octanethiol), to C10 (1-decanethiol) at the water-hexane interface. These 2D films show strong collective localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) extinction bands that are tunable via near-field coupling of adjacent Au NPs. Pronounced chain-length-dependent red shifts of the SPR bands have been observed for the PEI-capped Au films. The obtained PEI-capped Au films exhibit distinct interparticle-distance-dependent SERS characteristics.
C1 [Kim, In-Hyun; Kim, Ji Hoon; Shin, Kuan Soo] Soongsil Univ, Dept Chem, Seoul 06978, South Korea.
   [Shin, Kuan Soo] Soongsil Univ, Dept ICMC Convergence Technol, Seoul 06978, South Korea.
   [Choi, Jeong-Yong] Seoul Natl Univ, Dept Chem, Seoul 08826, South Korea.

TI SiP2S monolayer: A two dimensional semiconductor with a moderate band
   gap
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE First principles prediction; SiP2S monolayer; Electronic properties;
   optical properties
ID LATTICE THERMAL-CONDUCTIVITY; STRAIN; PHOSPHORENE; PREDICTION; GRAPHENE
AB In this work, by using first principles calculations, a new two dimensional structure namely SiP2S monolayer with rectangular atomic configuration is theoretically predicted. Our simulations proved that SiP2S monolayer indicates a good stability suggests its promise for experimental realization. Exploring the electronic properties shows that the proposed monolayer is an indirect semiconductor with a moderate band gap of about 1.19 eV calculated by HSE06 level of theory. Optical properties calculations show that this monolayer exhibits good absorption in low energy region of the electromagnetic spectrum. These results propose this new monolayer as a promising material for opto-electronic devices.
C1 [Naseri, Mosayeb] Islamic Azad Univ, Dept Phys, Kermanshah Branch, Kermanshah, Iran.

   Kermanshah, Iran. M. Naseri would like to thank Soheila Gholipour, Yasna
   Naseri and Viana Naseri for their interests in this work.

TI The pure rotational spectrum of YbOH
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE YbOH rotational spectrum
ID SPECTROSCOPY
AB The pure rotational spectrum of YbOH has been recorded and analyzed to produce fine and magnetic hyperfine parameters for the (X) over tilde (2)Sigma(+)(0, 0, 0) state. These parameters are compared with those determined from the optical study (Melville and Coxon, 2001) and with the values for YbF (Dickinson et al., 2001). The results support the existence of an unobserved perturbing state near the (A) over tilde (2)Pi(1/2) state, similar to that previously found in YbF. The precisely determining parameters lays the foundation for laser cooling YbOH, which will aid in the search for new physics beyond the standard model.
C1 [Nakhate, Sanjay; Steimle, Timothy C.] Arizona State Univ, Sch Mol Sci, Tempe, AZ 85287 USA.
   [Pilgram, Nickolas H.; Hutzler, Nicholas R.] CALTECH, Div Phys Math & Astron, Pasadena, CA 91125 USA.
RP Steimle, TC (reprint author), Arizona State Univ, Sch Mol Sci, Tempe, AZ 85287 USA.
OI Hutzler, Nicholas/0000-0002-5203-3635
FU Heising-Simons Foundation [2018-0681]

   grant from the Heising-Simons Foundation (Grant 2018-0681).

TI High-strength, thermal-stable ZrO2 aerogel from
   polyacetylacetonatozirconium
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE ZrO2 aerogel; Polyacetylacetonatozirconium; Mechanical strength; Thermal
   stability
ID METAL-OXIDE AEROGELS; SOL-GEL METHOD; ZIRCONIA AEROGEL; STABILIZED
   ZIRCONIA; PROPYLENE-OXIDE; SURFACE-AREA; ACID; TRANSITION; FIBERS; ROUTE
AB Polyacetylacetonatozirconium was used as the precursor to synthesize ZrO2 aerogel (PAZ-ZrO2). The physical properties of the aerogel were compared with those generated from zirconyl chloride (ZOC-ZrO2) and zirconyl nitrate (ZON-ZrO2). PAZ-ZrO2 aerogel has higher compressive strength (0.12-0.23 MPa) with lower density (0.12 +/- 0.005 g/cm(3)) as compared to ZOC-ZrO2 and ZON-ZrO2 aerogel, of which the mechanical strengths are in the range of 0.02-0.15 MPa and the density of 0.13-0.17 g/cm(3). After being treated at 1000 degrees C, the surface area (pore volume) of ZOC-ZrO2, ZON-ZrO2 and PAZ-ZrO2 aerogel are 210 m(2)/g (1.299 cm(3)/g), 223 m(2)/g (0.444 cm(3)/g) and 236 m(2)/g (1.568 cm(3)/g) respectively.
C1 [Liu, Benxue; Liu, Xiaochan; Zhao, Xinfu; Fan, Huili; Zhang, Jing; Yi, Xibin; Gao, Min] Qilu Univ Technol, Adv Mat Inst, Shandong Prov Key Lab Special Silicone Containing, Shandong Acad Sci, Jinan 250014, Shandong, Peoples R China.
   [Zhu, Luyi; Wang, Xinqiang] Shandong Univ, State Key Lab Crystal Mat, Jinan 250100, Shandong, Peoples R China.
   [Zhu, Luyi; Wang, Xinqiang] Shandong Univ, Inst Crystal Mat, Jinan 250100, Shandong, Peoples R China.
RP Liu, BX; Yi, XB (reprint author), Qilu Univ Technol, Adv Mat Inst, Shandong Prov Key Lab Special Silicone Containing, Shandong Acad Sci, Jinan 250014, Shandong, Peoples R China.

TI Conjugation of biomolecules onto antimonene surface for biomedical
   prospects: A DFT study
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Amino acid; Antimonene; Electronic properties; Optical properties;
   Density functional theory
ID DENSITY-FUNCTIONAL THEORY; AMINO-ACID ADSORPTION; PHOTOTHERMAL THERAPY;
   1ST-PRINCIPLES; GRAPHENE; NANOMATERIALS; MONOLAYERS; GLYCINE
AB In the reported work, we have approached the interaction of the amino acids onto the antimonene (Sb) monolayer by using density functional theory (DFT). Here, we have considered glycine (Gly), glutamic (Glu), histidine (HIE/His) and phenylalanine (Phe) biomolecules for interaction. The structural, electronic and optical properties have been investigated to understand the behavior. The adsorption of the biomolecules on Sb monolayer show the physisorption process. The adsorption energy of the phenylalanine (Phe) biomolecules is the most favorable. The optical absorption peaks of systems come in the near visible region. The studies conclude that Sb monolayer is useful for the bio-integrated electronics based devices.

TI A new potential energy surface of the LiHO+ system and the dynamics
   studies of the O + LiH+ reaction
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Potential energy surface; Quasi-classical trajectory method; Reaction
   dynamics; Differential cross section; Integral reaction cross section
ID AB-INITIO; CROSS-SECTIONS; CHEMISTRY; PLUS; STEREODYNAMICS; STATE;
   COEFFICIENTS; PATHWAYS; LIH2+
AB A potential energy surface (PES) for the lowest (2)A' state of LiHO+ is constructed using ab initio calculations. The MRCI method with AVQZ and AV5Z basis sets is employed during the calculations. The artificial neural network is utilized to fit the analytical PES based on 28,552 energy points which are extrapolated to the complete basis set limit The reaction dynamics of the O + LiH+ -> Li+ + HO reaction is investigated by means of quasi-classical trajectory method. The dynamics results show that the reaction mechanism dominating the title reaction changes from indirect to direct mechanism with increasing collision energy.
C1 [He, Di; Zhang, Tianqi; Wang, Meishan] Ludong Univ, Sch Phys & Optoelect Engn, Yantai 264025, Peoples R China.

TI Magnetically recoverable Ag/Bi2Fe4O9 nanoparticles as a
   visible-light-driven photocatalyst
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Nanoparticles; Recoverable photocatalyst; AR/Bi2Fe4O9; Magnetic
   materials
ID BI2FE4O9 NANOPARTICLES
AB This paper reports magnetically recoverable Ag/Bi2Fe4O9 nanoparticles (BFO NPs) using as a photoexcited catalyst. The Ag NPs are uniformly distributed on the surface of BFO NPs. Compared to BFO NPs, the decomposition rate of methyl orange for Ag/BFO NPs under the visible-light is greatly enhanced due to the high surface plasmon resonance and electron conductivities of Ag NPs. Moreover, Ag/BFO NPs have a higher saturation magnetization than BFO NPs, which makes them can be collected easily under magnetic fields. Therefore, Ag/BFO NPs are potential recoverable visible-light-driven photocatalyst for environmental pollutants degradation.
C1 [Wang, Kai; Xu, Xiaoguang; Wu, Yong; Miao, Jun; Jiang, Yong] Univ Sci & Technol Beijing, Sch Mat Sci & Engn, Beijing 100083, Peoples R China.

TI Tuning the porosity of TiO2 nanoparticles via surfactant-templated
   aerosol process for enhanced photocatalytic reactivity
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Aerosol process; Porous TiO2 nanoparticles; Photocatalysts; Surfactants;
   Specific surface area
ID MESOPOROUS TIO2; HYBRID NANOFIBERS; SPRAY-PYROLYSIS; WATER;
   PHOTOACTIVITY; NANOCRYSTALS; PARTICLES; SPHERES; PHASE; FILMS
AB In this work, we fabricated crystallite solid and porous TiO2 nanoparticles (NPs) using a surfactant-templated aerosol process. Specifically, Brij-58 surfactant was employed as a template in TiO2 matrix. The porosity of TiO2 NPs was controlled by varying the amount of Brij-58. The effect of TiO2 porosity on the photocatalytic reactivity was systematically examined. As a result, the highly porous TiO2 NPs exhibited much better photocatalytic reactivity than the low porosity TiO2 NPs. This suggests that the particle size, crystallite structure, and specific surface area play an important role in enhancing the photocatalytic reactivity of the TiO2 NPs.
C1 [Ku, Ji Hye; Kim, Ho Sung; Kim, Soo Hyung] Pusan Natl Univ, Coll Nanosci & Nanotechnol, Dept Nano Fus Technol, 30 Jangjeon Dong, Busan 609735, South Korea.

TI Structural characterization of Co-doped Pd-n (n=1-12) clusters:
   First-principles calculations
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE PdnCo clusters; Palladium-cobalt; DFT
ID MAGNETIC-PROPERTIES; PALLADIUM CLUSTERS; AB-INITIO; GROUND-STATE;
   CATALYST; ROBUST; PT-12; H-2
AB The structure of Co-doped Pd-n (n = 1-12) clusters is investigated using density functional theory (DFT) global optimization based on simulated annealing. The earlier putative global minimum of Pd12Co is now confirmed to be an icosahedron (I-h) with the Co atom in the center site, while unexpectedly cage structures are found for Pd-9(-)11 Co clusters, which are different than the icosahedral fragments. The results show, that doping with a Co atom increases the stability of Pd-n clusters and enhances their magnetic moment in the range of 1-3 mu(B). Ferromagnetic (FM) ordering between the Co atom and the Pd-n host are energetically favored.
C1 [Rodriguez-Kessler, P. L.] Ctr Invest & Estudios Avanzados, Dept Fis Aplicada, Unidad Merida, Km 6 Antigua Carretera Progreso,Apdo Postal 73, Merida 97310, Yucatan, Mexico.

TI Influence of Pb on structure, optical and electrical properties of
   Zn1-XPbXS semiconductor compounds at low temperatures
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Ternary semiconductor; Energy gap; Electrical conductivity; Activation
   energy
ID THIN-FILMS; ZNS
AB Zn1-XPbXS (x = 0-0.4 in steps of 0.1) ternary semiconductor samples have been prepared by co-precipitation method. The structural, optical and electrical studies have been carried out on all these samples to understand the influence of Lead on these properties. X-ray diffractograms showed that all Zn1-XPbXS samples have polycrystalline nature with Hexagonal phase. The room temperature optical absorption studies revealed that energy gap decreases with increase of Pb in Zn1-XPbXS compounds. The temperature-dependent conductivity, measured in the range 300-4 K, led to understand that the conduction mechanisms at 60 K and 30 K are different. The activation energies evaluated at low (300-60 K) and very low temperature (60-30 K) regions are 38.03-32.58 meV and 17.99-13.56 meV respectively. Activation energy and conductivity of Zn1-XPbXS samples increase with the increase of Pb. The samples exhibited low freezing temperature points indicating the possibility of their use in low temperature device applications.
C1 [Reddy, Y. Vasudeva; Kumar, T. Mohan; Nagabhushanam, M.] Osmania Univ, Dept Phys, Hyderabad 500007, Telangana, India.
   [Reddy, Y. Vasudeva] Govt Degree Coll, Dept Phys, Ibrahimpatnam 501506, Telangana, India.
   [Shekharam, T.] Matrusri Engn Coll, Dept Phys, Hyderabad, Telangana, India.

TI [8] Cyclo-1, 4-naphthylene: A possible new member in hole transport
   family
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE DFT; Vertical ionization energy; Adiabatic ionization energy; Hole
   transport; Vertical electron affinity; Adiabatic electron affinity;
   Electron transport; OLED
ID OXIDATION-REDUCTION REACTIONS; DENSITY-FUNCTIONAL THEORY;
   ELECTRON-TRANSFER; MOLECULAR MATERIALS; IRIDIUM COMPLEXES;
   CHARGE-TRANSPORT; ENERGY; ELECTROLUMINESCENCE; APPROXIMATION; EFFICIENCY
AB In this work, we report a new cyclic molecule, [8] Cyclo-1, 4-naphthylene ([8]-CN), that can act as an effective hole transport molecule. Based on First principle calculation we have quantified the reorganization energy of the compound to explore its efficiency as a hole transport molecule. Further, the molecule was functionalized with several electron donating (ED)/withdrawing(EW) groups to investigate the effect on the hole/electron transport property. We have found that the energy difference between indium tin oxide (ITO) work function and HOMO energy of ED group substituted ([8]-CN) are almost comparable while the situation is not suitable for EW group substituted [8]-CN.

TI Unexpected change in NOE with increasing temperature: Crosstalk between
   chemical exchange and cross relaxation in a NiN2S2 complex
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE NMR; Nuclear Overhauser Effect (NOE); Chemical exchange; Metal-ligand
   complexes; Tetradentate complexes
ID NUCLEAR-MAGNETIC-RESONANCE; CONFORMATIONAL EXCHANGE; SPIN-DIFFUSION;
   SPECTROSCOPY; ELUCIDATION; SEPARATION; NETWORKS; LIGANDS; SYSTEMS
AB Typically, with increasing sample temperature the rotational correlation time of the molecule decreases, leading to a decrease in the relative nuclear Overhauser effect (NOE) enhancement In characterizing the (O-ethyl-L-cysteinato)-Ni(II) in the solution state, the measured NOE enhancement increases with increasing sample temperature. This unexpected change is explained via crosstalk between nuclear spin cross relaxation and an additional chemical exchange phenomenon between the amino protons of the molecule. The case study using a relaxation matrix approach, with both cross relaxation and chemical exchange, could be essential to understanding a metal complex with a bidentate amino acid derived ligands.
C1 [Dougherty, Ryan J.; Golden, Melissa L.; Krishnan, V. V.] Calif State Univ Fresno, Dept Chem, Fresno, CA 93740 USA.
   [Krishnan, V. V.] Univ Calif Davis, Sch Med, Dept Pathol & Lab Med, Davis, CA 95616 USA.

TI EMI shielding performance of phenolic-based carbon foam modified with
   GO/SiO2 hybrid nanomaterials
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE GO/SiO2 hybrid nanomaterials; Phenolic-based carbon foam; Conductivity;
   Electromagnetic shielding
ID MECHANICAL-PROPERTIES; COMPOSITES; NANOTUBES; LIGHTWEIGHT; MORPHOLOGY;
   OXIDE
AB A facile way has been investigated to fabricate the phenolic-based carbon foam (PCF) modified with the unique three-dimensional structure of graphene oxide/SiO2 (GO/SiO2) hybrid nanomaterials which were obtained via in-situ preparation method. Results showed that the carbon foam sample modified by 1.5 wt% GO/SiO2 hybrid nanomaterial with a particle size of 80 nm had an electromagnetic interference shielding effectiveness (EMI SE) up to similar to 50 dB in X-band only at a thickness of 10 mm. This phenomenon may be ascribed to stable porous structure and nanoparticles assisting in attenuating the electromagnetic wave transmittance. The result enables their application in lightweight electromagnetic protection devices.
C1 [Zeng, Yao; Luo, Xia; Yu, Kejing; Qian, Kun] Jiangnan Univ, Minist Educ, Key Lab Ecotext, Wuxi 214122, Jiangsu, Peoples R China.
RP Yu, KJ (reprint author), Jiangnan Univ, Minist Educ, Key Lab Ecotext, Wuxi 214122, Jiangsu, Peoples R China.

   Zhou, F

   Zhu, Zhenyu
TI High-efficiency and environment-friendly sterilization PEVE coatings
   modified with Bi2WO6/TiO2 composites
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Bi2WO6; TiO2; Fluorocarbon resin coatings; Sterilization
ID PHOTOCATALYTIC ACTIVITY; G-C3N4; NANOPARTICLES; DEGRADATION; OXYGEN;
   NANOSHEETS; DYE
AB TiO2/Bi2WO6 composite photocatalysts prepared by a simple one-step hydrothermal method was added to a fluorocarbon resin coaling to improve the latter's antibacterial property. The sterilization performance of the TiO2/Bi2WO6-PEVE coaling was then detected via a photocatalytic sterilization experiment, a cycle sterilization experiment, and coaling interval sterilization. Results showed that the treated PEVE coaling achieves the best sterilization property under visible light when the mass ratio of TiO2 to Bi2WO6 is 7.5:100. After exposure to strong visible light for 1 h, nearly 80% of the bacteria attached to the coaling surface loses their activity. X-ray diffraction, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, UV-visible light spectrophotometry, Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface area analysis, scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy were employed to determine the structural and morphological characteristics of the obtained products. The TiO2 nano/microspheres adhered to the surface of the Bi2WO6 nanosheets and increased the latter's specific surface area and electron transmission efficiency. A marine sterilization cycle experiment confirmed that the TiO2/Bi2WO6 composite photocatalyst can be added to PEVE coatings. This work provides a reference for the future application of photocatalytic coatings in marine environments.
C1 [Chai, Yong Heng; Zhou, Feng; Zhu, Zhenyu] Dalian Maritime Univ, Key Lab Ship Machinery Maintenance & Manufacture, Dalian 116026, Peoples R China.
RP Zhou, F (reprint author), Dalian Maritime Univ, Key Lab Ship Machinery Maintenance & Manufacture, Dalian 116026, Peoples R China.
EM zhoufeng99@mails.tsinghua.edu.cn
RI Zhou, Feng/E-5275-2013; Zhou, Feng/J-9460-2019
OI Zhou, Feng/0000-0002-1715-2380; Zhou, Feng/0000-0002-1715-2380

   Foundation of China [21676040]; National Science Foundation of Liaoning
   ProvinceNatural Science Foundation of Liaoning Province [2015020184];
   Program for Liaoning Excellent Talents in University [LJQ2015013];
   Fundamental Research Funds for the Central UniversitiesFundamental
   Research Funds for the Central Universities [3132016065, 3132016341]
FX This work is supported by the National Nature Science Foundation of
   China (No. 21676040), National Science Foundation of Liaoning Province
   (2015020184), Program for Liaoning Excellent Talents in University

TI Mechanical impregnation of Pd-Sn/alumina and Cu-Mn/graphite on charcoal
   to minimise carbon monoxide emissions
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Carbon monoxide; Catalyst-impregnated charcoal; Residual CO
ID COPPER MANGANESE OXIDE; CO OXIDATION; TEMPERATURE; PALLADIUM; STOVES;
   PERFORMANCE; ADSORPTION; CATALYSTS; GRAPHENE; SUICIDE
AB This study investigated how to minimize carbon monoxide (CO) emissions from charcoal by impregnating with Pd-Sn/alumina and Cu-Mn/graphite. Samples were heated isothermally with continuous monitoring of residual CO using electrochemical and infra-red sensors. With 0.2 wt% Pd-Sn/alumina, 26.9% and 44.4% were recorded as lowest and highest residual CO. On the other hand, when 2 wt% Cu-Mn/graphite was used, 15.6%, and 25.3% were observed as lowest and highest residual CO. The activity of the catalysts decreased with temperature and increased with catalyst loading. This method could be used on briquettes, wood boiler chips and other solid carbonaceous materials to minimise CO emissions.
C1 [Nyombi, A.; Wessling, R.] Cranfield Univ, Cranfield Forens Inst, Def Acad United Kingdom, Shrivenham SN6 8LA, England.
   [Williams, M. R.] Cranfield Univ, Ctr Def Chem, Def Acad United Kingdom, Shrivenham SN6 8LA, England.
RP Nyombi, A (reprint author), Cranfield Univ, Cranfield Forens Inst, Def Acad United Kingdom, Shrivenham SN6 8LA, England.
EM a.nyombi@cranfield.ac.uk
OI Nyombi, Antony/0000-0003-0577-3099

   Haines Memorial Trust

   assisting at different stages of the experimental work.

TI Prediction of enthalpy for the gases CO, HCl, and BF
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Enthalpy; Closed-form representation; Carbon monoxide; Hydrogen
   chloride; Boron fluoride
ID THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES; WORMHOLE FORMATION; CARBON-MONOXIDE;
   REACTIVE-DISSOLUTION; ADSORPTION; DIOXIDE; PHASE; GASIFICATION;
   EQUILIBRIUM; ABSORPTION
AB We present a universal efficient closed-form representation for the molar enthalpy of gaseous substances. The predicted molar enthalpy values show excellent agreements compared to the experimental data in a wide temperature range for the gases CO, HCl, and BF. The proposed model is away from the need of plenty of experimental spectroscopy data, and depends on only four molecular constants, for which the experimental values can be easily found in the literature.
C1 [Jiang, Rui; Jia, Chun-Sheng; Wang, Yong-Qing; Peng, Xiao-Long; Zhang, Lie-Hui] Southwest Petr Univ, State Key Lab Oil & Gas Reservoir Geol & Exploita, Chengdu 610500, Sichuan, Peoples R China.

TI Reaction of ClF and Cl-2 with PH2X: The oxidation of P(III) to P(V)
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Phosphorus oxidation; P(III) binary complexes; Transition structures;
   P(V) molecules; P-13 chemical shieldings; EOM-CCSD spin-spin coupling
   constants
ID GAUSSIAN-BASIS SETS; CORRELATED MOLECULAR CALCULATIONS; BODY
   PERTURBATION-THEORY; COMPLEXES; PAIR; DERIVATIVES; ENERGIES; PNICOGEN;
   BONDS; BORON
AB Ab initio MP2/aug'-cc-pVTZ calculations have been performed to examine the oxidation of P(III) to P(V) in reactions involving FCl and Cl-2 as the oxidizing agents of PH2X molecules, for X = F, Cl, H, NC, and CN. Stable P(III) binary complexes and P(V) molecules, and the transition states which connect these minima exist on all (PH2X + ClF) and (PH2X + Cl-2) potential surfaces. Profiles of binding energies, P-31 chemical shieldings, and EOM-CCSD spin-spin coupling constants J(P-Cl) on these surfaces exhibit similar patterns, with minimum values for transition structures.

TI Effects of purity in single-wall carbon nanotubes into rubber
   nanocomposites
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Single-wall carbon nanotubes; Silicone rubber; Purity; Sonication;
   Nanocomposites
ID DISPERSION; GRAPHENE; REINFORCEMENT; STATE
AB Two types of pristine single-wall carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) were used: one with > 70% carbon element (P70) and another with > 90% carbon element (P90). After fitting of scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images, it was found that impurity in P70 have around 26%, P70 sonicated have around 17%, and P90 have around 9%. The rubber nanocomposites were prepared by mixing room-temperature-vulcanized (RTV) silicone rubber with pristine and sonicated SWCNTs. SEM shows that the filler particles were distributed uniformly throughout the rubber matrix. At 3 per hundred parts of rubber (phr), low resistance was obtained: similar to 94 kilo ohms (k Omega) (P70 SWCNTs), similar to 89 k Omega (sonicated P70 SWCNTs), and similar to 35 k Omega (P90 SWCNTs). The results show that the new model and modified Guth-Gold Smallwood model fit well with the experimental data. These improvements could be useful for next-generation devices such as actuators and energy harvesting.
C1 [Kumar, Vineet; Lee, Dong-Joo] Yeungnam Univ, Sch Mech Engn, 280 Daehak Ro, Gyongsan 38541, Gyeongbuk, South Korea.
RP Lee, DJ (reprint author), Yeungnam Univ, Sch Mech Engn, 280 Daehak Ro, Gyongsan 38541, Gyeongbuk, South Korea.
EM djlee@yu.ac.kr

   of South Korea (NRF) - Ministry of Education, South Korea
   [2017R1D1A3B03031732]; Yeungnam University, research fund South Korea in
   2018

   Yeungnam University, research fund South Korea in 2018.

TI Jet-cooled spectroscopy of the isomeric chloro-p-xylyl radicals in a
   corona-excited supersonic expansion
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Spectroscopy; 2-Chloro-p-xylyl radical; 3-Chloro-p-xylyl radical; Corona
   discharge
ID DENSITY-FUNCTIONAL THEORY; EXCITATION-ENERGIES; EMISSION-SPECTRA;
   VIBRONIC SPECTROSCOPY; BENZYL; STATES; DISCHARGE; APPROXIMATION;
   METHYLBENZYL
AB We report the jet-cooled isomeric chloro-p-xylyl radicals in a corona-excited supersonic expansion (CESE), and its vibronic spectrum was recorded with a long-path monochromator. By the precursor 2-chloro-p-xylene, we identified the two isomeric benzyl-type radicals, 2-chloro-p-xylyl and 3-chloro-p-xylyl radicals in the corona discharge. The vibronic emission spectrum of the chloro-p-xylyl radicals corresponded to the D-1 -> D-0 electronic transition and determined the electronic transition energy depending on the constitutional isomers.

TI Quantum trajectory study of laser-driven atomic ionization
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Quantum dynamics; Quantum trajectory method; Time-dependent quantum
   mechanics; Photoionization
ID WAVE-PACKET DYNAMICS; HYDRODYNAMIC EQUATIONS; HARMONIC GENERATION;
   DIFFRACTION
AB A methodology of quantum dynamics based on interacting trajectories without reference to any wave function is applied to ultrashort laser ionization of a model hydrogen atom. The pulses are chosen to be so short that the relative phase between the carrier wave and the pulse envelope becomes important As main results we show that the trajectory-only approach is capable of correctly describing the large amplitude motion and energetics of the laser driven electron and of reproducing carrier-envelope effects onto the photoelectron spectra. It also provides an intuitive picture of the dynamical quantum processes involved.
C1 [Cruz-Rodriguez, L.; Meier, C.] Univ Paul Sabatier, IRSAMC, LCAR, Toulouse, France.
   [Cruz-Rodriguez, L.; Uranga-Pina, L.; Martinez-Mesa, A.] Univ La Habana, Fac Fis, DynAMoS Dynam Proc Atom & Mol Syst, Havana, Cuba.
RP Meier, C (reprint author), Univ Paul Sabatier, IRSAMC, LCAR, Toulouse, France.

TI Understanding photoresponsive catechol-based polyoxotitanate molecules:
   A combined experimental and first principles investigation
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Polyoxotitanate; Photocurrent; Solar cell; First principles
ID SOLAR-CELLS; POLYOXOMETALATE CLUSTERS; ORGANIC-DYE; PHASE; WINDOW
AB In this study, we employ a type of polyoxotitanate (POT) compound with a unique structure that is composed of a metal-oxo core and functionalized by catechol ligands, and characterize its electrochemical and photoresponsive properties. We find that the POT functionalized by the catechol ligand acts as a photoresponsive single source to provide the photocurrent in aqueous electrolyte. The first principles calculation confirms the intramolecular ligand-to-metal charge transfer characters. Considering the stable photocurrent output generated by the POT in the aqueous condition, we anticipate potential applications of the catechol-functionalized POT in the optoelectronic devices that require water stability and aesthetic features.
C1 [Zhang, Lei] Nanjing Univ Informat Sci & Technol, Jiangsu Key Lab Optoelect Detect Atmosphere & Oce, Nanjing 210044, Jiangsu, Peoples R China.

TI First theoretical probe for efficient enhancement of nonlinear optical
   properties of quinacridone based compounds through various modifications
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Quinacridone-based dyes; Molecular modeling; Donor and acceptor units;
   Density functional theory; NLO properties; Two-state model
ID INTRAMOLECULAR CHARGE-TRANSFER; 1ST-ORDER HYPERPOLARIZABILITY; NLO
   PROPERTIES; CHROMOPHORES; DONOR; DESIGN; DYES; DERIVATIVES; ENERGIES;
   CRYSTAL
AB In this study, first attempt has been made for theoretical designing of quinacridone (QA) dye and new QA-based compounds (QA-1 to QA-9) were proposed by installing auxiliary donors (dimethylvinyl, methoxy, and N,N-dimethylamine), donor (diphenylamine) and acceptors (cyanoacrylic acid, CN and NO2) segments into fixed pi-bridge QA. DFT and TDDFT calculations with B3LYP/6-31G(d,p) and CAM-B3LYP/6-31G(d,p) functional were used to shed light on the promising structure, charge transport and NLO properties. Introduction of auxiliary donors/donor and acceptor successfully modified the structure which led to superior NLO properties. An eye-catching NLO response was observed in all designed compounds. Interestingly, QA-9 exhibits appealingly large enhancement in NLO properties through ICT process with < alpha > and beta(tot) computed to be 716.02 (a.u) and 128082.15 (a.u) respectively. UV-Vis results indicates the QA-9 most red shifted among all studied compounds with lambda(max) = 489.02 nm. QA-1 to QA-9 showed narrow HOMO-LUMO energy gap as compared to QA which results in enhanced NLO response. NBO analysis confirms the formation of charge separation state in QA-1 to QA-9 due to successful migration of electrons from auxiliary donors/donor to acceptors via pi-bridge. The present research evokes the scientific interest regarding the development of QA based tempting NLO compounds that can be beneficial in modern hi-tech applications.
C1 [Khan, Muhammad Usman; Ibrahim, Muhammad; Gulzar, Tahsin; Zia, Khalid Mahmood] Govt Coll Univ, Dept Appl Chem, Faisalabad 38000, Pakistan.
   [Khalid, Muhammad; Qureshi, Munawar Saeed] Khwaja Fareed Univ Engn & Informat Technol, Dept Chem, Rahim Yar Khan 64200, Pakistan.
   [Al-Saadi, Abdulaziz A.; Janjua, Muhammad Ramzan Saeed Ashraf] KFUPM, Dept Chem, Dhahran 31261, Saudi Arabia.
RP Janjua, MRSA (reprint author), KFUPM, Dept Chem, Dhahran 31261, Saudi Arabia.
EM ibrahim@gcuf.edu.pk; muhammad.khalid@kfueit.edu.pk; Janjua@kfupm.edu.sa
FU Deanship of Scientific Research (DSR) at King Fahd University of
   Petroleum & Minerals (KFUPM) [SR161009]
FX The author would also like to acknowledge the support provided by the
   Deanship of Scientific Research (DSR) at King Fahd University of
   Petroleum & Minerals (KFUPM) for funding this work through project No.
   SR161009.

TI Cyclic voltammetry, relativistic DFT calculations and biological test of
   cytotoxicity in walled-cell models of two classical rhenium (I)
   tricarbonyl complexes with 5-amine-1,10-phenanthroline
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE fac-rhenium tricarbonyl; 5-Amine-1,10-phenanthroline; Spin-Orbit DFT,
   cytotoxicity; Bacteria; Yeasts
ID OPTICAL-PROPERTIES; DIIMINE COMPLEXES; LIGAND; 2,2'-BIPYRIDINE;
   MICROSCOPY; CHARACTER; OXIDATION; BINDING; YEASTS
AB fac-[Re(CO)(3)(5-amine-1,10-phenanthroline)Cl or Br] (D1 and D2) were synthesized and characterized. D2 was obtained by al alternative method. The electrochemical reaction mechanisms of both D1 and D2 corresponded to EEC for reduction, and ECE for oxidation. Moreover, geometry, electronic, and luminescent properties were analyzed by relativistic DFT and TD-DFT calculations. We determined the lability of -Cl and -Br by a Morokuma-Ziegler analysis. We found that these compounds were less toxic than the ligand alone, and it depends on the cell model tested, where bacteria seem to be more susceptible than yeasts.

TI Model building of metal oxide surfaces and vibronic coupling density as
   a reactivity index: Regioselectivity of CO2 adsorption on Ag-loaded
   Ga2O3
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
ID PHOTOCATALYTIC CONVERSION; CYCLOADDITIONS; REDUCTANT; EVOLUTION; H2O
AB The step-by-step hydrogen-terminated (SSHT) model is proposed as a model for the surfaces of metal oxides. Using this model, it is found that the vibronic coupling density (VCD) can be employed as a reactivity index for surface reactions. As an example, the regioselectivity of CO2 adsorption on the Ag-loaded Ga2O3 photo-catalyst surface is investigated based on VCD analysis. The cluster model constructed by the SSHT approach reasonably reflects the electronic structures of the Ga2O3 surface. The geometry of CO2 adsorbed on the Ag-loaded Ga2O3 cluster has a bent structure, which is favorable for its photocatalytic reduction to CO.
C1 [Kojima, Yasuro; Ota, Wataru; Teramura, Kentaro; Hosokawa, Saburo; Tanaka, Tsunehiro; Sato, Tohru] Kyoto Univ, Grad Sch Engn, Dept Mol Engn, Nishikyo Ku, Kyoto 6158510, Japan.
   [Ota, Wataru; Sato, Tohru] Kyoto Univ, Fukui Inst Fundamental Chem, Sakyo Ku, Takano Nishihiraki Cho 34-4, Kyoto 6068103, Japan.
   [Teramura, Kentaro; Hosokawa, Saburo; Tanaka, Tsunehiro; Sato, Tohru] Kyoto Univ, Unit Elements Strategy Initiat Catalysts & Batter, Nishikyo Ku, Kyoto 6158510, Japan.
RP Sato, T (reprint author), Kyoto Univ, Fukui Inst Fundamental Chem, Sakyo Ku, Takano Nishihiraki Cho 34-4, Kyoto 6068103, Japan.

TI Ab initio calculation for isomerization reaction kinetics of
   nitrobenzene isomers
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE PES; Nitrobenzene; Transition states; Isomerization; Rate constant
ID BASIS-SET; DECOMPOSITION; MECHANISM; PHOTODISSOCIATION; IMPLEMENTATION;
   COMBUSTION
AB The potential energy surface (PES) of nitrobenzene isomers has been built by CCSD(T)/CBS methods. The geometries of isomers and transition states (TSs) are optimized at BHANDHLYP/6-311 + + G (d, p) level. Sixteen isomers and fifteen isomerization reactions of nitrobenzene were found. The rate constants for the isomerization reactions are calculated and compared according to different types of isomerization. The rate constants and activation energies (Ea) of all reactions are fitted using a qusi-Arrhenius equation. Branching ratios of the nitrobenzene isomerization reactions and the previously reported decomposition reactions are compared and the isomerization to C6H5O-NO followed by cleavage of O-NO dominates the decomposition of nitrobenzene at low temperature.
C1 [Gao, Zhongquan; Yang, Meng; Tang, Chenglong; Yang, Feiyu; Fan, Xiangshan; Yang, Rui; Huang, Zuohua] Xi An Jiao Tong Univ, State Key Lab Multiphase Flow Power Engn, Xian 710049, Shaanxi, Peoples R China.

TI Sonochemical synthesis and high-efficient solar-light-driven
   photocatalytic activity of novel cobalt and manganese codoped tungsten
   oxide nanoparticles
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Co/Mn-W3O8 nanoparticles; Sonochemical; Solar light; Pollutants
ID VISIBLE-LIGHT; FACILE SYNTHESIS; COMBUSTION SYNTHESIS;
   MAGNETIC-PROPERTIES; ASSISTED SYNTHESIS; BISMUTH MOLYBDATE; ZINC
   MOLYBDATE; AZO-DYE; WATER; WO3
AB This work presents a new approach to preparation of Co/Mn-W3O8 nanoparticles via facile sonochemical route. Cobalt and manganese codoped tungsten oxide (W3O8) nanoparticles was studied as a photocatalyst for the removal of amaranth under solar light irradiation (lambda(max) 520 nm). The results indicated that the Co/Mn-W3O8 composite photocatalyst showed higher photocatalytic activity the single element doped and pure W3O8. Moreover, the stability of Co/Mn-W3O8 was tested using recycling experiments. It is suggested that the band gap energy difference between the Co/Mn-W3O8 and W3O8 accelerates the separation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs, dominating the enhanced photocatalytic activity.

TI Intermolecular electron energy transfer processes in the quenching of
   N-2(C-3 Pi(u),v=0-4) by collisions with N-2 molecules
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
ID RATE COEFFICIENTS; VIBRATIONAL-RELAXATION; RATE CONSTANTS; PHOTOMETRIC
   MEASUREMENTS; LOWER THERMOSPHERE; NITROGEN; STATE; EXCITATION; N2;
   OXYGEN
AB The removal rates of electronically excited molecular nitrogen N-2(C-3 Pi(u),v = 0-4) in the collisions with the ground state N-2(X-1 Sigma(+)(g),v* = 0-4) molecules are calculated according to analytical expressions. The study includes a consideration of intermolecular electron energy transfers with the electronic excitation of target molecules. Reasonable agreement of the calculated rate coefficients with data of experimental measurements is obtained.

TI A general theory for heterogeneous coupled chemical reaction-thermal
   diffusion systems
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
DE Chemical reaction-thermal diffusion system; Engineering of chemical
   reaction; Energy equation; Entropy and entropy production rate
   equations; Gibbs equation; Evolution equation; Governing equation
AB Many transport and rate processes in chemical, physical and biological systems, are controlled by the coupled chemical reaction-thermal diffusion process. Though many literatures, including the literatures of engineering of chemical reactions, discussed this coupled problem, but a unified rigorous theory and a unified method based on the chemical thermodynamics are lacked. In this paper we give a general thermodynamic theory including complete energy conservation equation, entropy equation, evolution equations of the heat conduction and the mass diffusion, especially the complete governing equations of these couple systems. The theory given here revises previous theories, clearly shows which factors should be considered and is valuable for the engineering of chemical reaction and other transport and rate processes.
C1 [Kuang, Zhen-Bang] Shanghai Jiao Tong Univ, Sch Naval Architecture Ocean & Civil Engn, Shanghai 200240, Peoples R China.
RP Kuang, ZB (reprint author), Shanghai Jiao Tong Univ, Sch Naval Architecture Ocean & Civil Engn, Shanghai 200240, Peoples R China.
EM Zbkuang@mail.sjtu.edu.cn

TI Adsorption for SO2 gas molecules on B, N, P and Al doped MoS2: The DFT
   study
SO CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
ID SINGLE-LAYER MOS2; NANOSTRUCTURE ADSORBENT; GRAPHENE; SURFACE; SENSOR;
   NO2
AB In this paper, we investigated SO2 adsorption on B, N, P and Al doped MoS2, which band structure, density of states, charge transfer, etc by the density function theory (DFT) calculation. Results show that the SO2 prefer to be absorbed at the top of Mo atom of MoS2. It is found that SO2 is strongly adsorbed on Al-MoS2 with considerable adsorption energy of -1 to -2.33 eV, however, the best adsorption position is the top of Mo atom of Al-MoS2, which the biggest E-a is -2.33 eV, the best charge is -0.343e and the shortest d is 1.763 angstrom. So these findings confirm that Al-MoS2 can be used to detect the presence of SO2 in the environment.
C1 [Zhang, Ruiyang; Sun, Chunbao] Univ Sci & Technol Beijing, Sch Civil & Resource Engn, Beijing 100083, Peoples R China.
